ancestors.content:
2Ô∏è‚É£ Here's the 2nd post highlighting key new features of the upcoming v259 release of systemd. #systemd259 #systemd

If you have systemd v259 on your system, and you run "ldd /usr/lib/systemd/systemd" (i.e. query the shared library deps of the systemd service manager binary), then you get the following output:

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

ancestors.content:
libcrypt.so.2 => /lib64/libcrypt.so.2 (0x00007f4511fcb000)
libcrypto.so.3 => /lib64/libcrypto.so.3 (0x00007f4511000000)
/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f451250e000)
libz.so.1 => /lib64/libz.so.1 (0x00007f4512384000)

And that's it.

Do you notice something about this output?

No? I'll give you a hint, it's not about what's in it, it's really about what is not in it.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

ancestors.content:
If you look at this closely, you should notice that the deps listed there now are only: systemd's own shared libraries, glibc/gcc stuff (libc, libm, ld-linux, libgcc_s), and only three other things: libcrypt, libcrypto and libz.

But how can this be? systemd used to link against pam, libselinux, tpm2-tss, lbacl, libblkid, libmount, libbpf, libcryptsetup, libaudit, libkmod, libpcre2, libp11-kit, libseccomp, liblzma, libzstd, liblz4, ‚Ä¶

But now they are all gone?

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

ancestors.content:
Yes, they indeed, at least kinda. With v259 we converted almost all our runtime dependencies to use dlopen() instead of explicit shared library linking. We started this process back in v247 with some "leaf" libraries, but with v259 we moved 7 more libraries over, so that in effect only two non-libc libraries remain that we link regularly to: libcrypt (aka the crypt() password hashing API) and libcrypto (aka OpenSSL, and the latter pulls in libz).

You might wonder why we do this?

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

ancestors.content:
It's really about footprint: with one exception you don't really need any of these deps in certain limited setups: when you run systemd inside of a container for example.

You wonder about that one exception? That's util-linux' libmount API. We actually need it for the service manager to run, so even though it's now a weak dependency it really isn't if you run the main systemd binary. You might wonder why bother then? The reason is to ensure that libsystemd.so‚Ä¶

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

ancestors.content:
‚Ä¶(which is a library a myriad of other programs link to) can have a tiny dependency footprint too.

Or in other words, if you try to build a minimal container image, then it's certainly not systemd that's going to be the dependency hog that blows up its size.

Now, you might wonder about package managers: they tend to automatically generate package dependencies from shared library dependencies, so if we get rid of those, are we breaking all package managers?

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

descendants.content: Oh, and it's not just about footprint actually, it's also about security: by ensuring that dynamic libraries only get loaded when they are actually used, we make it harder for exploits such as the openssh/xz incident last year to take place, as compile time deps no longer translate to runtime deps 1:1, and thus awful concepts such as gcc constructors lose their negative impact a bit.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

descendants.content:
And one last thing: what about those last two deps? i.e. openssl and libcrypt?

Yes, we have plans to turn those into dlopen() deps too. Hopefully in v260.

And once we achieve that things are going to be fun, because systemd will start to have a smaller minimal dep footprint than certain other "lightweight" init systems. For example, that dependency hog s6 is currently at 3 shared library deps beyond libc. So wasteful! And it doesn't even do a fraction of what systemd does...

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

descendants.content:
You might specifically wonder why we haven't turned the libcrypt dep into dlopen() yet, given it only exposes basically a single relevant function (a flavour of crypt()) and hence should be simple.

The only reason is that it's not quite *as* simple, because crypt() used to be part of glibc on Linux, and there are still systems around which do use it like that, hence we need some non-trivial ifdeffery to make that happen and keep things working in both scenarios, and so far we were too‚Ä¶

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

descendants.content:
‚Ä¶lazy for that.

And that's all for today.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

descendants.content: Or maybe let me add one more thing. systemd is of course not only the really fundamental package that makes up an OS image. There are various others you really need too. It would be fantastic of those adopted similar logic, so that container images for example never pull in libselinux anymore (which in turn pulls in libpcre and other stuff), or libaudit and so on, i.e. stuff that doesn't even do anything inside a container.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

descendants.content:
@pid_eins Now that was a random shot I did not expect. So I had to read the whole thread, and it was wild.

So. First, let's straighten up the record.

s6's pid 1, s6-svscan, depends on one shared library in addition to libc... and that is if you choose to link it dynamically, which is not the default. This library is from the skalibs package, the general C programming library used by every skarnet.org binary. It is a sane dependency to a package coming from the same origin, an explicit design choice to factor a set of C routines outside of applications, because I hate code duplication across packages.

There are a couple binaries in the s6 package that indeed depend on three libraries: one from the s6 package itself, so, not a dependency; one from the optional execline package also coming from the same origin; and the third one is skalibs. That is all.

The fact that s6 binaries can be linked against shared libraries is a concession to practical use in distributions, which prefer to use shared libraries for obvious maintenance and security reasons. As an individual, I generally prefer static linking, and it would be interesting to compare how s6 fares against systemd when all the libraries are statically linked...

... but that's irrelevant, because that's clearly not the path systemd is taking - and now we get to the important part.

The entire point of your thread was to brag that you removed shared libraries from the ldd output by using dlopen() instead of having them linked at exec time. (So, obviously, no static linking of these libraries.)

Lennart, that is not how simplifying dependencies works. That is not how any of this works.

Cleaning up ldd output by calling dlopen() does not remove dependencies. It just makes them less visible. You still depend on the external package, the difference is that

  • you do not have the validation step at link time: less static analysis
  • at run time, if the dependency is missing, you don't fail at execve() time, but at dlopen() time, which means later.

In other words, what you did made systemd less reliable, and more unpredictable. You removed opportunities to detect problems at link time, and you deferred the failure at run time; this goes against good engineering practices that say the earlier you fail, the better.

You did not remove the dependencies to pam, libselinux, tpm2-tss, lbacl, libblkid, libmount, libbpf, libcryptsetup, libaudit, libkmod, libpcre2, libp11-kit, libseccomp, liblzma, libzstd, liblz4. and more. You hid them.

And then you call s6 a "dependency hog" because in the worst possible case, one s6 program has an ldd output with 3 shared libraries in addition to the libc. Dude. Come on.

I am starting to believe that you are ashamed of the amount of dependencies in systemd. Good - that would be a healthy emotional response. But then the healthy action to take isn't to hide the dependencies then take a shot at critics by saying LOOK THEY HAVE MORE DEPENDENCIES THAN WE DO NOW OMG. The healthy action to take would be to... actually work at making some of your dependencies optional, by identifying exactly in what circumstances a given dependency is used, deciding if there's a viable alternative in its absence, possibly writing workarounds or stubs, and adding compile-time configuration switches.

I have said it before and I'll say it again: I welcome technical design discussions. But... is it too much to ask that they be of a slightly higher level?

dlopen() Metadata for ELF Files # Version Changes 1.0 Initial Release Target Audience # The target audience for this specification is:
Developers working on userspace subsystems that create ELF binaries that dynamically load libraries Developers working on userspace subsystems that package ELF binaries that dynamically load libraries Motivation # Using dlopen() to load optional dependencies brings several advantages: programs can gracefully downgrade a feature when a library is not available, and the shared library is only loaded into the process (and its ELF constructors are run) only when the requested feature is actually used.
